name: 4-bromo-2,6-difluoroaniline
Reason:
To predict the melting point of 4-bromo-2,6-difluoroaniline, the effects of substituents on the aniline base must be assessed quantitatively. Aniline has a basic melting point of -6°C. The substituents are expected to influence this value as follows: 
- Bromine atom: Bromine being a large, heavy halogen, generally increases intermolecular van der Waals forces significantly. We can estimate this effect to be approximately +40°C to the base melting point of aniline due to the size and polarizability of bromine.
- Fluoro groups (2x): Each fluorine is expected to contribute around +20°C to the melting point due to the induction effect and the ability of fluorine to participate in strong dipole-dipole interactions and form weak hydrogen bonds with NH. The combined effect of two fluoro groups would thus be approximately +40°C.
Therefore, the combined estimated effect of the bromine and fluorine atoms is +80°C to the aniline melting point.
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, aniline, has a melting point of about 6 degrees Celsius. 
- Bromine atom: +20 (due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals forces) 
- Fluorine atoms: +10 each (due to the electronegativity and the ability to engage in dipole-dipole interactions) 
- The presence of the amino group (NH2) in the aniline part of the molecule will contribute to the melting point through hydrogen bonding, which is not considered in the base value of aniline but will be included in the overall prediction. 
- The presence of the bromine and fluorine atoms will increase the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the polar nature of the molecule. 
##Prediction: 60.0
